article:
An 'extended play' ('EP') is a musical recording that contains more music than a
single, but is too short to qualify as a full studio album or LP. The term EP
originally referred to specific types of vinyl records other than 78 rpm
standard play (SP) records and LP records, Maes, Jan; Vercammen, Marc, and,
Baert, Luc (2001).
[http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=ddiwuUpODi8C&pg=PA2#v=onepage&q&f=false
Digital audio technology: a guide to CD, MiniDisc, SACD, DVD(A), MP3 and DAT].
Google Books via Focal Press. p. 2. but it is now applied to mid-length
Compact Discs and music downloads as well. Ricardo Baca of [[The Denver Post]]
said, "EPsâoriginally extended-play 'single' releases that are shorter than
traditional albumsâhave long been popular with punk and indie bands."
In the United Kingdom, the Official Chart Company defines a boundary between EP
and album classification at 25 minutes of length or four tracks (not counting
alternative versions of featured songs, if present). [http://c0903002.cdn.cloudfiles.rackspacecloud.com/3189-official-
singles-chart-rules.pdf Official UK Charts Singles Rules] [http://www.theofficialcharts.com/docs/NEW_Album_Chart_Rules_2007_2.pdf
Official Rules For Chart Eligibility â Albums]
